name: History of Psychology
description: A survey of developments in Western philosophy and science which influenced the emergence of modern psychology in the second half of the Nineteenth Century. Three basic problems are considered: mind-body, epistemology (science of knowledge), and behaviour/motivation/ethics. We begin with the ancient Greek philosophers, and then consider the contributions of European scholars from the Fifteenth through Nineteenth Centuries. Twentieth Century schools are discussed including: psychoanalysis, functionalism, structuralism, gestalt, behaviourism, and phenomenology. This course is restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in Specialist Programs in Psychology, Mental Health Studies and Psycholinguistics.
prerequisites: Two B-level half-credits in Psychology or permission of the instructor
